Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)

Solutions and Strategies

Facilitate the combining data from the whole class. Ask one pair or group at a time to report how many heads they had in 30 trials, and record the results in a table. (This could be done during the Explore time so it is ready for the Summary) Use Teaching Aid 1.1A: Class Data Summary (Coins) to record the class’s data. See the table below for an example.

The number of heads for each group may vary considerably, with some results far from 50%. You may want to also make a line plot with the possible number of heads (from 1 through 30) along the horizontal axis to illustrate the distribution of the class results.

After pairs or groups have all tossed their paper cup 30 times discuss their findings. (This could be done during the Explore time so it is ready for the Summary) Combine the data from all of the groups, and find the fraction and percent of times the paper cup landed on an end. Use Teaching Aid 1.1B: Class Data Summary (Cups) to record the class data.

Making the Mathematics Explicit

Suggested questions

  • How did the results of the coin toss compare to our predictions? (Answers will vary depending on the predictions.)
  • As the number of trials increases, what is happening to the percent of heads? (It is important for students to recognize that as the number of trials increases, the percent of heads approaches 50%.)
For example, if we accumulate the data from different groups, adding 30 more trials each time, the table might be as follows.

The Initial Challenge has two goals: to see that the ratio Heads/Total tosses changes as the number of events grows and to see that the ratio of Heads/Total stabilizes as number of events/trials grows.

If you collect data from several classes and report it on a coordinate graph showing the ratio Heads/Total tosses changing as the number of total tosses changes, you will see that the ratio Heads/Tails gets closer to 0.5, If you keep the raw data (Heads, Total tosses) as well as (Heads/Tails, Total tosses) you will also see that the difference between number of heads and ½ number of tosses grows. For example, after four tosses we might have (3 heads, 4 tosses) or (3/4, 4). We expect two heads. The ratio is far from the expected ½, but the raw number is only one more. After 100 tosses we might have (55 heads, 100 tosses) or (0.55, 100). The ratio is close to the expected 0.5 but the raw number is now 5 bigger than the expected 50. (Portrayal)

  • Is the ratio getting closer to 1:2? (Yes)
  • Is the number of heads getting closer to ½ number of tosses? (Yes)

(In one case we are thinking multiplicatively about a comparison, in the other additively.)

Results for individual groups with the cup toss are unlikely to be identical. As in the coin toss, you can add the data for each group one at a time, computing the fractions and percents with each additional group. Use Teaching Aid 1.1B: Class Data Summary to record the data. This can help students see where the relative frequency of landing on an end begins to level off.

  • How did the results of the cup toss compare to our predictions? (Answers will vary depending on the predictions.)
  • Did you all arrive at the same conclusion about which outcome (the paper cup landing on its side or the cup landing on an end) is more likely?
  • Does this fraction represent a ratio? (In this Problem there are two ratios: the number of times the cup lands on its side (or end) to the total number of tosses, and the number of times the cup lands on its side to the number of times it lands on its end.)
  • Is my (side landings)/50 = or ≠(class combined side landings)/50? (Answers will vary)
  • The 30 trials scale by how many groups of data we are collecting as a class? Do the number of side landings scale that way too? Does it create a proportion? (It is not a perfect set of data. Too many variables in the situation to control. Refer to question 4 in the What If to compare and contrast this idea.)
  • Do you agree with Ashley or Eli in What If Situation A?(Ashley is correct. The cup toss does not have a 50/50 chance of occurring.)

Now What Do Students Know

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions.

See answers to the Problem for more information about the strategies and embedded mathematics.

Reflecting on Student Learning  

Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.  

  • What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know Question?

  1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?
  • How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?
